capsules_submitted.utterance: I think McGonagall's glasses are really cool. I mean, who wouldn't want to wear a pair of magical square lenses? They're just so... unique and fitting for her character as a Transfiguration professor.

I think McGonagall's glasses are a bit of an iconic part of her character, don't you? I mean, who can forget those round lenses that seem to be staring right back at you? (laughs) But seriously, I think they're a great example of how J.K. Rowling used everyday objects to create a sense of depth and history in the wizarding world.
I think McGonagall's glasses are really cool, I mean, who wouldn't want to be able to see through solid objects? But, I have to admit, they do make her look a bit... stern.
capsules_submitted.reply: valeria, i think i trust you.

capsules_submitted.utterance: I think McGonagall's glasses are a bit of an iconic part of her character, and I've always been fascinated by the way they seem to add to her no-nonsense persona. But, I have to say, "square-lenses" is a pretty unique description - I wouldn't have thought of it that way myself!
capsules_submitted.reply: if you don't mind me asking. what kind of belongings does mcgonagall have?

capsules_submitted.utterance: I've met Hagrid a few times, and I have to say, he's really quite tall. I mean, it's not every day you see someone who's over 6 feet 8 inches standing in front of you! (laughs) The way the teachers at Hogwarts describe him as "hunchbacked" is actually kind of misleading - he's just got a lanky build, that's all.
capsules_submitted.reply: valeria, i think i trust you.
